text: 911 911 is a sort of a litmus test for
our humanity and that's a lovely sound
bite isn't it if you sense that there is
a sort of cynicism that's it creeps in
to even the topic it's because I think
like many people I'm suffering a kind of
fatigue I think I understood so well
when it happened I understood so well
how the life her life had changed almost
like losing a loved one I I felt
violated for three weeks afterwards I
don't know why was I felt something like
post-traumatic stress syndrome and I had
done nothing just being here now years
out I am a little spiritually drained
Norway just happened this horrible crime
just a few days ago every day there's an
atrocity coming at you it's hard to keep
911 pulsing and real and urgent as I
mean I'm jaded in a way i'd say
spiritually tired actually how did it
influence my work well i remember saying
bravely to some people that I I thought
that we should all go and do our best on
the site i was even saying we should go
and dance on the ruins you know
something i never did other people
attempted it but that was the impulse at
that time what have I done since then I
have made a piece about about war and
made more abstract pieces there is
always this feeling that I have and I'm
here on Times Square that at any moment
the world could change radically it
makes me love more profoundly does it
make a sense of urgency is they work
better well that's not for me to say is
it I suppose it's for the historians to
say has it changed the way I see the
city or the world of dance there's
something about middle age that makes
everything seem a bit absurd all one
strivings everything is just one step
away from being vanity vanity all is
vanity
in the dance world is not immune in my
eyes from that at all I still have to
struggle to find a reason to make
another movement I still have to
struggle deep down to really care enough
other than for self-promotion to really
want to get out there in the public eye
those things maybe were there before
nine eleven there's something uneasy
because I'm supposed to be more grateful
now for being alive I'm supposed to be
more motivated and on my off days I am
depressed on my on days like a day like
today I'm happy and I just want to get
back in the studio and do can I do I
think the dance can help make sense of
cataclysmic events this reminds me of a
question I got from a young african
artist who was working on her paper and
she was trying to talk speak for
disenfranchised and traumatized
communities Somalia and so on and she
asked the same question and I said
wherever people feel free enough to
express themselves wherever people feel
light enough they can defy gravity which
is a lot of what dancing is or define
time and aging and all those in distance
between us that is a victory this is one
of those questions like where were you
and Kennedy was shot isn't it sad
signposts but real I was coming into New
York for a meeting a board meeting I
think on fifty-third Street and as I
approached the I live north of the city
I approached the george washington
bridge and there was a policeman who
said to me in a line of people don't
even think about coming into manhattan
it closed today we were supposed to have
performed at the World Trade Center at
the an outdoor site on September 12 2001
there was no bill no venue the next day
but a year later the lower Manhattan
Cultural Council invited us down and we
did a concert at Battery Park and the
audience was there and was left among
those wonderful performances I've ever
given the evening was beautiful there
as a sense of gratitude we all knew that
we had clawed back and that things life
was striving to become normal again if
life ever is normal in New York not to
mention the cultural world but that was
a triumphant moment any lasting meaning
of take away the metaphysical one is the
only constant is change the other one is
we have to have courage to love what we
love and we have to know how to honor
our right to love and be together
nothing else we can say we don't control
it love what we love have courage
you
